Flying into Cancún vs Mexico City: Which Airport Should You Choose?

The Complete Guide to Picking Your Gateway to Mexico

Last updated: January 2025

Mexico has two major international gateways: Cancún (CUN) serves the Caribbean coast, while Mexico City (MEX) is the central hub connecting everywhere. Choosing the right airport can save you money, time, and hassle—or cost you all three if you choose wrong. Here's how to decide.

In This Guide

  • Quick Decision Guide
  • Cancún Airport (CUN) Overview
  • Mexico City Airport (MEX) Overview
  • Flight Prices Compared
  • Connection Times & Logistics
  • Ground Transportation from Each
  • Best Airport by Destination
  • Multi-Destination Strategy
  • New Airport: Felipe Ángeles (NLU)
  • Immigration & Customs Tips
  • Practical Recommendations

Quick Decision Guide

{<strong>Fly into Cancún (CUN) if:</strong></p><ul><li>Your destination is Riviera Maya, Tulum, Playa del Carmen, Cozumel, or Isla Mujeres</p><ul><li>You want the shortest path to beach resorts</p><ul><li>You're visiting only the Yucatán Peninsula</p><ul><li>You found a cheap direct flight from your home city</p><p><strong>Fly into Mexico City (MEX) if:</strong></p><ul><li>Your destination is Oaxaca, San Miguel de Allende, Guanajuato, or Pacific coast</p><ul><li>You're visiting Mexico City itself</p><ul><li>You're doing a multi-region trip</p><ul><li>You want the most flight options and best prices</p><ul><li>Your final destination has no direct flights from your country</p><p><strong>The Hybrid Approach:</strong> Many travelers fly into one and out the other—especially for multi-destination trips. Check "multi-city" fares; they're often barely more than round-trips.}

Cancún Airport (CUN) Overview

{<strong>The Beach Gateway</strong></p><p>Cancún International Airport is purpose-built for tourism. It's efficient, modern, and designed to get you to your resort fast.</p><p><strong>Key Stats:</strong></p><ul><li>4 terminals (T2, T3, T4 for international; T1 domestic)</p><ul><li>25+ million passengers annually</p><ul><li>Direct flights from 100+ cities worldwide</p><ul><li>Immigration: 30-60 minutes typical</p><ul><li>Distance to Hotel Zone: 20 minutes</p><ul><li>Distance to Playa del Carmen: 45-60 minutes</p><ul><li>Distance to Tulum: 90-120 minutes</p><p><strong>Serves These Destinations:</strong></p><ul><li>Cancún Hotel Zone (20 min)</p><ul><li>Puerto Morelos (25 min)</p><ul><li>Playa del Carmen (45-60 min)</p><ul><li>Cozumel (ferry from Playa, +45 min)</p><ul><li>Tulum (90-120 min)</p><ul><li>Riviera Maya resorts (30-90 min)</p><ul><li>Valladolid (2 hours)</p><ul><li>Mérida (3.5-4 hours)</p><ul><li>Holbox (2.5 hours + ferry)</p><p><strong>Pros:</strong></p><ul><li>Extremely well-connected internationally</p><ul><li>Tourism-focused infrastructure</p><ul><li>Many resort transfers included in packages</p><ul><li>Competition keeps prices reasonable</p><ul><li>Efficient for beach vacation arrivals</p><p><strong>Cons:</strong></p><ul><li>Aggressive timeshare sales in arrival hall</p><ul><li>Transfer costs add up for distant destinations</p><ul><li>Limited connections to non-Yucatán Mexico</p><ul><li>Can be chaotic during peak seasons}

Mexico City Airport (MEX) Overview

{<strong>The Central Hub</strong></p><p>Mexico City's Benito Juárez International Airport is Latin America's busiest, connecting everywhere in Mexico and beyond.</p><p><strong>Key Stats:</strong></p><ul><li>2 terminals (T1 international/domestic mix, T2 Aeroméxico hub)</p><ul><li>50+ million passengers annually</p><ul><li>Direct flights from 150+ cities</p><ul><li>Immigration: 45-90 minutes typical</p><ul><li>Connects to every Mexican destination</p><ul><li>New Felipe Ángeles Airport (NLU) is alternative</p><p><strong>Serves These Destinations:</strong></p><ul><li>Mexico City itself</p><ul><li>San Miguel de Allende (3-4 hours by bus)</p><ul><li>Guanajuato (4-5 hours by bus, or fly to BJX)</p><ul><li>Querétaro (2.5 hours by bus)</p><ul><li>Oaxaca (1-hour flight or 6-hour bus)</p><ul><li>Puerto Vallarta (1-hour flight)</p><ul><li>Los Cabos (2-hour flight)</p><ul><li>Anywhere in Mexico via connections</p><p><strong>Pros:</strong></p><ul><li>Best flight prices (most competition)</p><ul><li>Connects to everywhere in Mexico</p><ul><li>Gateway to colonial heartland</p><ul><li>Mexico City is worth exploring</p><ul><li>Excellent bus connections nationwide</p><p><strong>Cons:</strong></p><ul><li>Larger, more complex airport</p><ul><li>Longer immigration lines</p><ul><li>Altitude adjustment needed (7,350 ft)</p><ul><li>Far from beach destinations</p><ul><li>Traffic can make city transfers slow}

Flight Prices Compared

{<strong>Typical Price Patterns:</strong></p><p><strong>From US East Coast (NYC, Miami, Atlanta):</strong></p><ul><li>To Cancún: $250-450 round trip</p><ul><li>To Mexico City: $300-500 round trip</p><ul><li>Winner: Cancún (more competition, charter flights)</p><p><strong>From US West Coast (LA, SF, Seattle):</strong></p><ul><li>To Cancún: $350-550 round trip</p><ul><li>To Mexico City: $300-450 round trip</p><ul><li>Winner: Mexico City (closer, more flights)</p><p><strong>From Europe:</strong></p><ul><li>To Cancún: $600-900 round trip</p><ul><li>To Mexico City: $550-800 round trip</p><ul><li>Winner: Mexico City (more carriers, better connections)</p><p><strong>From Canada:</strong></p><ul><li>To Cancún: CAD $400-700 round trip</p><ul><li>To Mexico City: CAD $500-800 round trip</p><ul><li>Winner: Cancún (heavy Canadian tourism)</p><p><strong>Budget Tip:</strong> Mexico City often has the cheapest fares, then add a $50-100 domestic flight to your final destination. Total can beat direct Cancún flights, especially off-peak.</p><p><strong>When Cancún Wins:</strong></p><ul><li>Charter flight deals (especially from cold-weather cities)</p><ul><li>Package deals with hotels</p><ul><li>Peak beach season when MEX-CUN flights are expensive}

Connection Times & Logistics

{<strong>If Connecting Through Mexico City:</strong></p><p><strong>Domestic Connections:</strong></p><ul><li>Minimum connection: 2 hours (same terminal), 3 hours (different terminals)</p><ul><li>Terminal transfer: Free shuttle, 15-20 minutes</p><ul><li>Re-check bags: Usually automatic on same ticket</p><ul><li>Immigration: Done on arrival, not at connection</p><p><strong>Popular MEX Connections:</strong></p><ul><li>MEX → Oaxaca (OAX): 1 hour, 6+ daily</p><ul><li>MEX → Puerto Vallarta (PVR): 1.5 hours, 10+ daily</p><ul><li>MEX → Los Cabos (SJD): 2.5 hours, 15+ daily</p><ul><li>MEX → Huatulco (HUX): 1 hour, 3-4 daily</p><ul><li>MEX → Mérida (MID): 1.5 hours, 8+ daily</p><p><strong>If Connecting Through Cancún:</strong></p><p>Cancún has limited domestic connections—it's designed as a destination, not a hub. Flights to:</p><ul><li>Mexico City: 2.5 hours, many daily</p><ul><li>Oaxaca: Rare, usually via MEX</p><ul><li>Guadalajara: 3 hours, few daily</p><p><strong>The Verdict:</strong> For connections, Mexico City wins decisively. Cancún is a destination airport, not a hub.}

Ground Transportation from Each

{<strong>From Cancún (CUN):</strong></p><p><strong>To Hotel Zone:</strong></p><ul><li>Shared shuttle: $15-25/person</p><ul><li>Private transfer: $50-70 total</p><ul><li>Taxi: $50-60 (fixed rate)</p><ul><li>Bus (ADO): $5-8/person</p><ul><li>Time: 20-30 minutes</p><p><strong>To Playa del Carmen:</strong></p><ul><li>ADO Bus: $12-15/person, every 30 min</p><ul><li>Shared shuttle: $25-35/person</p><ul><li>Private transfer: $80-100 total</p><ul><li>Time: 45-75 minutes</p><p><strong>To Tulum:</strong></p><ul><li>ADO Bus: $18-22/person</p><ul><li>Private transfer: $120-150 total</p><ul><li>Time: 90-120 minutes</p><p>---</p><p><strong>From Mexico City (MEX):</strong></p><p><strong>To Mexico City Hotels:</strong></p><ul><li>Metro: $0.50 (T1 only, not recommended with luggage)</p><ul><li>Metrobús: $1 (T1 and T2)</p><ul><li>Authorized taxi: $15-25</p><ul><li>Uber/Didi: $10-20</p><ul><li>Time: 30-60 minutes depending on traffic</p><p><strong>To San Miguel de Allende:</strong></p><ul><li>Primera Plus/ETN Bus: $35-45, 4 hours</p><ul><li>Private transfer: $200-300</p><ul><li>Rental car: 3-4 hours drive</p><p><strong>To Bus Station (TAPO/Norte):</strong></p><ul><li>Metro + walking: $0.50</p><ul><li>Taxi: $10-15</p><ul><li>Time: 30-45 minutes}

Best Airport by Destination

{<strong>Beach Destinations:</strong></p><p>| Destination | Best Airport | Why | |-------------|--------------|-----| | Cancún Hotel Zone | CUN | 20 min away | | Playa del Carmen | CUN | 45-60 min | | Tulum | CUN | 90-120 min | | Cozumel | CUN | Ferry from Playa | | Riviera Maya resorts | CUN | 30-90 min | | Isla Mujeres | CUN | Ferry from Cancún | | Holbox | CUN | 2.5 hrs + ferry | | Puerto Vallarta | PVR or MEX | Direct to PVR best | | Los Cabos | SJD or MEX | Direct to SJD best | | Huatulco | HUX or MEX | Direct or connect |</p><p><strong>Colonial/Cultural:</strong></p><p>| Destination | Best Airport | Why | |-------------|--------------|-----| | Mexico City | MEX | You're there | | San Miguel de Allende | MEX or BJX | Bus from either | | Guanajuato | BJX or MEX | BJX closer | | Oaxaca | OAX or MEX | Direct flight or bus | | Querétaro | MEX or QRO | 2-hour bus from MEX | | Puebla | MEX | 2-hour bus | | Mérida | MID or CUN | MID direct better |</p><p><strong>Adventure:</strong></p><p>| Destination | Best Airport | Why | |-------------|--------------|-----| | Copper Canyon | CUU (Chihuahua) | Train starts there | | Baja road trip | TIJ or SJD | Depends on direction | | Chiapas | TGZ or MEX | Tuxtla direct better |}

Multi-Destination Strategy

{<strong>Open-Jaw Tickets:</strong></p><p>Flying into one city and out another often costs the same as round-trip. Smart routings:</p><p><strong>Beach + Colonial:</strong></p><ul><li>In: Cancún → Riviera Maya → Mérida → fly to MEX → San Miguel → Out: Mexico City</p><ul><li>In: Mexico City → Oaxaca → fly to CUN → Tulum → Out: Cancún</p><p><strong>Pacific + Caribbean:</strong></p><ul><li>In: Puerto Vallarta → Sayulita → fly to CUN → Tulum → Out: Cancún</p><ul><li>In: Los Cabos → La Paz → fly to MEX → fly to CUN → Out: Cancún</p><p><strong>Grand Tour:</strong></p><ul><li>In: Mexico City → Oaxaca → Chiapas → Yucatán → Out: Cancún</p><ul><li>This routing moves logically south and east</p><p><strong>Booking Tips:</strong></p><ul><li>Search "multi-city" on Google Flights</p><ul><li>Compare: multi-city vs two one-ways vs round-trip + domestic</p><ul><li>Budget airlines (Volaris, VivaAerobus) for domestic legs</p><ul><li>Book domestic separately for flexibility}

New Airport: Felipe Ángeles (NLU)

{<strong>Mexico City's Second Airport</strong></p><p>Opened in 2022, Felipe Ángeles International Airport (NLU) is 45km north of Mexico City center. It's being positioned as an alternative to congested MEX.</p><p><strong>Current Status:</strong></p><ul><li>Limited international flights (growing)</p><ul><li>Mostly low-cost carriers (Volaris, VivaAerobus)</p><ul><li>Some US routes (Dallas, Houston, LA)</p><ul><li>Significantly less convenient location</p><p><strong>Should You Use NLU?</strong></p><p><strong>Consider NLU if:</strong></p><ul><li>Significantly cheaper flight</p><ul><li>Staying north of Mexico City</p><ul><li>Connecting to domestic budget carriers</p><ul><li>Flight times work better</p><p><strong>Avoid NLU if:</strong></p><ul><li>Staying in Roma/Condesa/Centro</p><ul><li>Tight connection times</p><ul><li>First visit to Mexico City</p><ul><li>You value convenience over savings</p><p><strong>Transfer from NLU:</strong></p><ul><li>To city center: 1-2 hours depending on traffic</p><ul><li>Limited public transport</p><ul><li>Taxi/Uber: $40-60</p><ul><li>Not yet as developed for tourism</p><p><strong>The Verdict:</strong> For most tourists, MEX remains the better choice despite congestion. NLU is improving but not yet convenient for most trips.}

Immigration & Customs Tips

{<strong>At Cancún (CUN):</strong></p><p><strong>Immigration:</strong></p><ul><li>Have your FMM form ready (filled online saves time)</p><ul><li>Passport valid 6+ months</p><ul><li>Return ticket may be requested</p><ul><li>Hotel address ready</p><ul><li>Typical wait: 30-60 minutes</p><ul><li>E-gates available for some nationalities</p><p><strong>Customs:</strong></p><ul><li>Red/green light system (random inspection)</p><ul><li>Declare items over $500 value</p><ul><li>No fresh fruits/meats</p><ul><li>Reasonable alcohol/tobacco limits</p><p><strong>Timeshare Warning:</strong> After customs, you'll face aggressive timeshare salespeople posing as "tourism officials." Walk past firmly. Your real transfer will be outside the terminal, not inside.</p><p>---</p><p><strong>At Mexico City (MEX):</strong></p><p><strong>Immigration:</strong></p><ul><li>Longer lines than Cancún typically</p><ul><li>Same FMM requirements</p><ul><li>Business vs tourism questions more common</p><ul><li>Typical wait: 45-90 minutes</p><ul><li>Global Entry/trusted traveler helps</p><p><strong>Customs:</strong></p><ul><li>Same red/green system</p><ul><li>More thorough than Cancún sometimes</p><ul><li>Duty-free purchases tracked</p><p><strong>Terminal Tips:</strong></p><ul><li>T1 and T2 are separate buildings</p><ul><li>Domestic connections often require terminal change</p><ul><li>Free shuttle between terminals (every 10 min)</p><ul><li>Allow 30 minutes for terminal transfer}

Practical Recommendations

{<strong>First-Time Mexico Visitors:</strong></p><ul><li>Beach vacation: Fly Cancún, simple and direct</p><ul><li>Cultural trip: Fly Mexico City, explore the capital first</p><ul><li>Mixed trip: Open-jaw (in one, out other)</p><p><strong>Budget Travelers:</strong></p><ul><li>Search MEX first (usually cheapest)</p><ul><li>Add domestic flights on Volaris/VivaAerobus</p><ul><li>Consider overnight buses to save on flights + hotels</p><ul><li>Tuesday/Wednesday departures cheapest</p><p><strong>Luxury Travelers:</strong></p><ul><li>Direct flights to final destination when available</p><ul><li>Private transfers pre-arranged</p><ul><li>Lounge access makes connections pleasant</p><ul><li>Consider charter flights to remote destinations</p><p><strong>Families:</strong></p><ul><li>Minimize connections with kids</p><ul><li>Cancún for beach resorts (most direct)</p><ul><li>Book transfers in advance (no taxi hunting)</p><ul><li>Consider red-eye flights (kids sleep)</p><p><strong>Solo Travelers:</strong></p><ul><li>MEX gives most flexibility</p><ul><li>Easy bus connections from MEX</p><ul><li>Budget airlines for spontaneous trips</p><ul><li>More comfortable traveling light through hubs}

Frequently Asked Questions

Is Cancún airport safe?

Yes, Cancún airport is very safe and tourist-friendly. The main annoyance is aggressive timeshare sales in the arrival hall—walk past them confidently. Use authorized transportation (ADO bus, official taxi booths, pre-booked transfers) and you'll have no issues.

Can I fly into Cancún and visit Mexico City?

You can, but it's inefficient. Cancún to Mexico City is a 2.5-hour flight or 20+ hour bus. If Mexico City is on your itinerary, fly there directly or use an open-jaw ticket. The only exception: if Cancún is significantly cheaper and you're doing a long trip anyway.

Which airport has better food and amenities?

Mexico City (MEX) has more dining options and lounges due to its size. Cancún has adequate food courts and some lounges, but it's designed for quick transfers to resorts, not extended stays. Neither is a destination airport—get to your hotel.

Should I worry about altitude at Mexico City airport?

Mexico City is at 7,350 feet elevation. Most people feel fine, but some experience mild symptoms (shortness of breath, fatigue) the first day. Take it easy, stay hydrated, limit alcohol initially. If you're going directly to a beach destination, you won't notice.

What about flying into other Mexican airports?

Direct flights to your destination are often best: Puerto Vallarta (PVR), Los Cabos (SJD), Guadalajara (GDL), Oaxaca (OAX), and Mérida (MID) all have international service. Check direct flight availability before defaulting to CUN or MEX connections.
